questions.text: In a group of 100 people, the average GFR is 85ml/min with a standard deviation of 25. What is the range for 90% confidence interval:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ref.: K.park's Textbook of preventive and social medicine 22 /e p 793 Confidence Intervals The Lower Limit and Upper Limit estimates for the Statistic are given as: Lower Limit: statistic - C x SE (statistic) Upper Limit: statistic+ C x SE (statistic) .Standard Error, SE= {Standard Deviation / n} n = sample size Confidence coefficient: C = Confidence coefficient = 1.65 for 90% confidence interval = 1.96 for 95% confidence interval = 2.58 for 99% confidence interval In this question: n = 100; SD = 25 SE= 25/ 100 = 2.5 Lower limit= 85- (1.65 x 2.5) = 85 - 4 = 81 Upper limit= 85+ (1.65 x 2.5) = 85 + 4 = 89 Hence, 90% CI will be 81-89

choices.text: Not given for infant less than 6 months
Two primary doses given to children in the one to three year age group
Booster doses are given after 1 year and repeated every 3 year
In endemic areas vaccination is given to cover childern between one to nine years age group

questions.text: Regarding japanese encephalitis vaccine, what is not true
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ref.: K.Park's 'Textbook of preventive and social medicine' 22/e p261 in endemic areas the vaccine is given to children in the 1 to 15 years age group. The Haddon Matrix is the most commonly used paradigm in the injury prevention field.Developed by William Haddon in 1970, the matrix looks at factors related to personal attributes, vector or agent attributes and environmental attributes; before, during and after an injury or death. By utilizing this framework, one can then think about evaluating the relative importance of different factors and design interventions.

questions.text: Haddon matrix is related to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Injury prevention. It systematically analyzes injury events by considering the interplay of various factors—host, agent, and environment—across three distinct phases: pre-event, event, and post-event. This structured approach allows public health professionals and safety experts to identify multiple points for intervention, thereby developing comprehensive strategies to prevent injuries from occurring or to mitigate their severity once they do. For instance, in a car crash, it would consider factors like driver behavior (host), vehicle design (agent), road conditions (environment) before, during, and after the impact, leading to diverse prevention measures.

questions.text: The blood pressure data of 200 persons were collected the first quartile BP of the data was 94 Hg and third quartile was 110mm Hg . How many patients have blood pressures between the 3rd and 4th quartile is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref.: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartile First quartile (designated also called the lower quartile or the 25th percentile (splits off the lowest 25% of data from the highest 75%). Second quartile (designated Q2) also called median or the 50"' percentile (cuts data set in half). Third quartile (designated Q3) also called the upper quartile or the 75"' percentile (splits off the highest 25% of data from the lowest 75%). Interquartile range (designated IQR) is the difference between the upper and lower quartiles. (IQR= Q3- QI) In the given question, between every two quartiles one/ fourth of the total number of patients are present, i.e. 200/4 = 50 patients.

questions.text: In a study two groups of newborns are checked for their weights based on whether mothers received food supplements or not. The appropriate test which can be used for comparing the data is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ref.: K.park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 22/e p795 • Parametric test: assumes normality of a data. Data should be symmetrical. Not used for skewed data a. Student T test b. Paired T test c. ANOVA test • Non-parametrcal test:Normality is not necessary. used for skewed data. Used in presence of any outlier. a. Mann-whittney test b. Wilcoxen signed rank test c. Kruskal wallis test

questions.text: Screening is not useful in which carcinoma
questions.solution: D Ref.: Harrison's principles of internal medicien 18/e p661 Most testicular cancers are first detected by the patient, either unintentionally or by self-examination. Some are discovered by routine physical examination. However, no studies have been done to determine the effectiveness of testicular self-examination or clinical testicular examination in reducing mortality from testicular cancer. Based on fair evidence, screening for testicular cancer would result in unnecessary diagnostic procedures with attendant morbidity.

questions.text: Data about recent trends of immunization in the community can be found by
questions.solution: B Ref.: K.Park's ' Textbook of Preventive and social Medicine' 22e/ p 786 Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) are nationally-representative household surveys that provide data for a wide range of monitoring and impact evaluation indicators in the areas of population, health, and nutrition. DHS Survey Types There are two types of DHS surveys: • Standard DHS Surveys have large sample sizes (usually between 5,000 and 30,000 households) and typically are conducted about every 5 years, to allow comparisons over time. • Interim DHS Surveys focus on the collection of information on key performance monitoring indicators but may not include data for all impact evaluation measures (such as mortality rates). These surveys are conducted between rounds of DHS surveys and have shorter questionnaires than DHS surveys. Although nationally representative, these surveys generally have smaller samples than DHS surveys.

questions.text: Which of the these Statements is true about Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana?
questions.solution: a. Cashless benefit on Presenting smartcard and fingerprints Ref: https://rsby.gov.in/ RSBY- THE SCHEME RSBY has been launched by Ministry of Labour and Employment, Government of India to provide health insurance coverage for Below Poverty Line (BPL) families. The objective of RSBY is to provide protection to BPL households from financial liabilities arising out of health shocks that involve hospitalization. Eligibility Unorganized sector workers belonging to BPL category and their family members (a family unit of five) shall be the beneficiaries under the scheme. It will be the responsibility of the implementing agencies to verify the eligibility of the unorganized sector workers and his family members who are proposed to be benefited under the scheme. The beneficiaries will be issued smart cards for the purpose of identification. Benefits The beneficiary shall be eligible for such in - patient health care insurance benefits as would be designed by the respective State Governments based on the requirement of the people/ geographical area. However, the State Governments are advised to incorporate at least the following minimum benefits in the package / scheme: • Total sum insured would be Rs. 30,000/- per family per annum on a family floater basis. • The unroganised sector worker and his family (unit of five) will be covered. • Cashless attendance to all covered ailments • Hospitalization expenses, taking care of most common illnesses with as few exclusions as possible • All pre-existing diseases to be covered • Transportation costs (actual with maximum limit of Rs. 100 per visit) within an overall limit of Rs. 1000. Funding Pattern • Contribution by Government of India: 75% of the estimated annual premium of Rs. 750, subject to a maximum of Rs. 565 per family per annum. The cost of smart card will be borne by the Central Government. • Contribution by respective State Governments: 25% of the annual premium, as well as any additional premium. • The beneficiary would pay Rs. 30 per annum as registration/renewal fee. • The administrative and other related cost of administering the scheme would be borne by the respective State Governments

questions.text: According to the new WHO 2013 malaria treatment guidelines which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution: c. Primaquine is contraindicated in infants and pregnant women Ref: https://nvbdcp.gov.in/doc/diagnosis-treatment -Malaria-2013.pdf Contraindications Primaquine is contraindicated in patients with known hypersensitivity to primaquine or related compounds and in patients with severe G6PD deficiency or severe nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) methaemoglobin reductase deficiency. Primaquine crosses the placenta and may cause haemolysis in a G6PD-deficient fetus; it is therefore not recommended for use during pregnancy or during breastfeeding unless the G6PD status of the infant is known. Use of primaquine in infants < 6 months is not advised because of lack of data on its safety.

questions.text: A researcher selected all possible samples from a population and plotted their means on a line graph. What is this distribution called as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sampling distribution Ref.: Research Methods for communication ScienceJames H. Walt There are three distinct types of distribution of data which are - 1.Population Distribution, characterizes the distribution of elements of a population drawn from the same population. 2.Sample Distribution, characterizes the distribution of elements of a sample drawn from a population 3.Sampling Distribution, describes the expected behavior of a large number of simple random samples Sampling distributions constitute the theoretical basis of statistical inference are of considerable importance in business decision-making. Sampling distributions are important in statistics because they provide a major simplification on the route to statistical inference.

questions.text: What is following type of data description called?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Stem and leaf diagram Ref: Wikipedia In a specific table called a "Stem and Leaf Plot," each data value is divided into a "stem" (the initial digit or digits) and a "leaf" (usually the last digit). To help visualize the shape of a distribution, a stem-and-leaf display is a tool for presenting quantitative data in a graphical style, comparable to a histogram. Two columns are divided by a vertical line in a straightforward stem-and-leaf layout. The stems are in the left column, and the leaves are in the right column

questions.text: Some medicine come with a label of ‘Store at a cool place only”. At what temperature should these medicines be kept?
questions.solution: a. 8-15°c Ref: k Park’s textbook of PSM 22/e p 100 A medication that should be stored at room temperature means between 15 to 25 degrees Celsius; cool temperature means between 8 to 15 degrees Celsius; refrigeration means between 2 to 8 degrees Celsius; and freezing temperature means -10 to -25 degrees Celsius.

questions.text: The mean systolic blood pressure was measured in a sample population of elderly females and came out to be 125 mm Hg with a standard deviation of 10.95 percent of people would have blood pressure above:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 110 mm Hg Ref: k Prak’s Textbook of PSM 22/e p 789 The standard deviation is a statistic that measures the dispersion of a dataset relative to its mean and is calculated as the square root of the variance. It is calculated as the square root of variance by determining the variation between each data point relative to the mean. If the data points are further from the mean, there is a higher deviation within the data set; thus, the more spread out the data, the higher the standard deviation.

questions.text: A drug which does not cure a disease but decreases its symptoms and increase survival leads to ?

questions.text: The following life cycle most closely resembles that of which of the following viruses?
questions.solution: c. Japanese encephalitis virus Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Micrbiology 8/e p 513-514. JEV is transmitted to humans through bites from infected mosquitoes of the Culex species (mainly Culex tritaeniorhynchus). Humans, once infected, do not develop sufficient viraemia to infect feeding mosquitoes. The virus exists in a transmission cycle between mosquitoes, pigs and/or water birds (enzootic cycle)

questions.text: Which of the following is used for selecting patient with respect to potential factors that will affect the results :
questions.solution: C Stratified random sampling Ref: K. Park’s Textbook of preventive and social Medicine “ 22/e p 792 Stratified random sampling is a method of sampling that involves the division of a population into smaller sub-groups known as strata. In stratified random sampling or stratification, the strata are formed based on members' shared attributes or characteristics. Stratified sampling is used to highlight differences between groups in a population, as opposed to simple random sampling, which treats all members of a population as equal, with an equal likelihood of being sampled.

questions.text: All of the following are duties of an ASHA worker except :
questions.solution: C Administering vaccines to children Ref: k park’s ‘Textbook of preventive and social medicine 22/e p413 ASHAs are local women trained to act as health educators and promoters in their communities. The Indian MoHFW describes them as: • health activist(s) in the community who will create awareness on health and its social determinants and mobilize the community towards local health planning and increased utilization and accountability of the existing health services. • Their tasks include motivating women to give birth in hospitals, bringing children to immunization clinics, encouraging family planning (e.g., surgical sterilization), treating basic illness and injury with first aid, keeping demographic records, and improving village sanitation.[6] ASHAs are also meant to serve as a key communication mechanism between the healthcare system and rural populations. • She will act as a depot holder for essential provisions being made available to all habitations like Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORS), Iron Folic Acid Tablet(IFA), chloroquine, Disposable Delivery Kits (DDK), Oral Pills & Condoms, eTC

questions.solution: C.Odds ratio/relative risk Ref : K. Park’s Textbook of preventive and social medicine ‘ 22/e p 75 Interpret odds ratio, compare value to • If odds ratio=1: odds of exposure is the same for cases and controls (no association between disease and exposure) • If odds ratio>1:odds of exposure among cases is greater than among controls (a positive association between disease and exposure) • If odds ratio <1: odds of exposure among cases is less than among controls (a negative, or protective, association between disease and exposure

questions.text: CA-125 is a marker for screening of ovarian cancer. To characterise this test, histopathlogical confirmation of ovarian cancer was done in a cohort of patients. 60/100 women who tested positive for this test actually had ovarian cancer. What is the negative predicitive value of this test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 80/100 Negative Predictive Value (NPV) refers to the proportion of individuals who truly do not have the disease among those who tested negative. In this question, it is assumed that 100 women tested negative. If 80 out of these 100 women truly did not have ovarian cancer, then: NPV = True Negatives / (True Negatives + False Negatives) = 80 / (80 + 20) = 80 / 100 = 80%. Hence, the negative predictive value is 80 out of 100. Incorrect options: A. 20/100 This would represent the false negatives, not the NPV. It tells how many people tested negative but actually had the disease, which is not what NPV measures. B. 40/100 This value corresponds to the false positives from the test-positive group and is not related to the NPV calculation. C. 60/100 This is the true positives among those who tested positive, which represents the positive predictive value (PPV), not NPV.

questions.text: A study was conducted to see the effect of pulse oximeter readings in neonates with and without micropore. A plot between the two values was made as shown in the figure below. What concusion can be drawn from the plot?
questions.solution: d. The curve shows a regression line means co-relation Ref: High yield biostatistics pg 106 A regression line is simply a single line that best fits the data (in terms of having the smallest overall distance from the line to the points). ... The formula for the best-fitting line (or regression line) is y = mx + b, where m is the slope of the line and b is the y-intercept.

questions.text: A study was done in 3 states to see the mean blood pressure in each community. Health workers were assigned and they visited each house in the three communities. Mean blood Pressure in each community was found and compared. What type of study design is represented here?

questions.text: Which of these is the best for determining the threshold for diagnosis of a positive test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ROC is used to evaluate the test's sensitivity and specificity. The probability ratio, which is crucial for establishing the test's threshold, is found using the tangent to the curve. The specificity diminishes with increasing sensitivity. The tangent of the curve aids in determining the test's accuracy criterion, which is high sensitivity without sacrificing specificity.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman from a dry state who ingested rye for long time presented with complaints of weakness in both the lower limbs, nausea and fatigue. Over due course of time, she is completely unable to walk, What is the likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lathyrus sativus Toxin : Beta Oxylyl Amino alanine ( BOAA) Food product : Lathyrus sativus ( Khesari dal) C/F : Neurological disease , affects the joints Knee> Hip - C/F : Give stages : A) Latent : Asymptomatic: Important stage for prevention ( remove dal from diet) B) No stick : Jerky steps , Limping gait C) One stick: Clumsy gait , One stick used to walk D) Two stick: Two stick used to walk E) Crawler inability: To walk/stand , Atrophy of thigh , bent knee Prevention methods : - Steeping - Parboiling with lime - Vit C prophylaxis - Avoid dal in diet

questions.text: A radiotherapist prescribes a new drug combination of chemotherapy and immunotherapy for metastatic melanoma. It prolongs the survival. Which of the following is true in this situation?
questions.solution: (b) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases Ref. Park 24th edition, Pg. 66 Metastatic Melanoma is a fatal disease and here the new regimen prolongs the survival. So the Duration of the disease is increased. Incidence – New cases occurring Prevalence - Both New and Old cases The new treatment increases the duration of the disease (for example from 2 months to 6 months). So the old cases keep on increasing at a point of time although the new cases occur at the usual rate. Prevalence=Incidence x Duration HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS AND NOTES ON THE RELATED TOPICS Prevalence increases with addition of diseased people or subtraction of healthy people Prevalence increases with increase in duration of disease or decrease in it’s Fatality.

90% of patients will be benefitted by giving the drug

questions.text: A researcher said he has discovers a new drug which is effective in chronic hypertensives with a p value of <0.10. which of the following is true regarding the same
questions.solution: c )Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance Ref. Oxford Handbook of Medical Statistics, Pg. 248 P VALUE IS PROBABILITY It lies between 0 to 1 It comes from a statistical test, that is testing a particular null hypothesis It means the expression of the strength of evidence in favour or against the null hypothesis The Definition is, it is the probability, given that the null hypothesis is true, of obtaining data as extreme or more extreme than that observed A P value is not the probability that the null hypothesis is true Usually 0.05 is taken as the cut off, and P<0.05 is statistically significant which means that the null hypothesis is true, and it expresses the probability of obtaining the study results by chance if the null hypothesis is true. The Null hypothesis is rejected in favour of alternative if the p value is less than alpha (pre determined level of significance) HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS AND NOTES ON TH RELATED TOPICS

questions.text: A patient was sputum negative for TB, but chest X-ray was suggestive for TB. Which is the next step according to RNTCP
questions.solution: (b) CB – NAAT Ref. Technical and Operational guidelines for TB control in india – 2016 DIAGNOSTIC ALGORITHM FOR TB All presumptive TB will undergo sputum smear examination If first sputum Is smear positive and not at risk of DR –TB, it will be categorised as microbiologically confirmed TB For Smear positive and presumptive MDR-TB, CB-NAAT will be performed to rule out Rifampicin resistance, and categorised as microbiologically confirmed drug sensitive RIF resistant TB If first smear is negative and chest X-ray is suggestive of TB, 2nd sample will be subjected to smear and CB-NAAT simultaneously CB Naat is Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test The Gene expert TB test detects DNA sequences specific for M.Tuberculosis and Rifampicin resistance by PCR. It is based on Cepheid Gene expert system, a platform for rapid and simple to use nuclei acid amplification tests (NAAT) Results are obtained within 90 minutes. It has minimal biohazard and needs very little technical training since unprocessed sputum samples are used to identify the results in a real time format. HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS AND NOTES ON THE RELATED TOPICS

questions.text: A study was conducted with the objective to compare the incidence of postpartum depression in mother as compared to the sex of the child. For assessment Edinburg Depression scaled score (EDSS) was used. The study was divided into mothers with male baby as one group to be compared with mothers with female baby. Which of the following statistical test will be used to determine the association?
questions.solution: (b) Chi-square test Ref. Oxford Textbook of Medical Statistics, Pg. I, ii, 252 Park 23rd edition, pg. 852 There are 2 groups Incidence is a qualitative variable – Presence of disease or Not The 2 groups are different Example: The incidence of postpartum depression in mothers with male baby are compared with mothers with female baby. But the statistical test for association is done between presence of depression as determine by EDSS by mothers with male baby against female baby group. For example: The results are as follows Group Mothers with male baby Mothers with female baby Incidence by EDSS 27% 30% Since the variable is equalitative, Yes or No type, chi-square Test will be used. if instead the scores are compared (instead of incidence), which comes as 25, 30 etc. as whole numbers, unpaired T test will be used. HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS AND NOTE ON THE RELATED TOPICS

questions.text: Below is the graph of CD4 count in HIV patients. From the graph below identify the mean CD 4 count.
questions.solution: (d) Between 300-400 Ref. Oxford Handbook of Medical statistics, Pg. 182 APPROACH Convert the graph into numbers approximately Small approximations like 20 or 21 will not after the answers..so do not worry Normal CD4 count ranges from 500-1600 cells/mm3 as per www.aids.gov Here we have intervals instead of direct data, so find the midpoints and then the usual procedure follows. CD4 Count Number of people <100 5 100-200 10 200-300 25 300-400 35 Mean=x1.n1+x2.n2+……….=34500/100=345 n1 + n2 +…………… The Arithmetic mean of a sample or a population is obtained by adding all of the observations and dividing by the number of observations. For large number of observations (usually>30) which does not include outliers, the mean score usually provides a better measure of central tendency. Option a It is false as theMean in 345 Option b It is not true as the answer is below 350 and above 300 Obtion c It is not the most suitable Option d It is the best suitable option

questions.text: Which point in the below natural history of disease marks the onset of symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref. Park 24th edition, Pg. 40 Point A marks the entry of infectious agent into the host Point B marks the subclinical phase where symptoms and signs are not visible, but the disease agent induces tissue and physiological changes Point C marks the Clinical horizon when symptoms and signs appear Point D is present inside the Clinical phase after the Clinical horizon The Natural history of disease can be divided into Prepathogenesis phase Pathogenesis phase The pathogenesis phase begins with the entry of the disease agent into the host The final outcome of the disease may be Recovery, Disability or Death The pathological changes are essentially below the level of Clinical horizon The Clinical stage begins when signs and symptoms appear.

questions.text: The following are the disease frequencies in a population. Based on the number of causes which of the following is the correct match Disease 1: Number of cases last week 42 this week 43 Disease 2: Number of cases last week 2 this week 42 Disease 3: Number of cases last week 6and present week 1
questions.solution: (a) Endemic, epidemic, sporadic Ref. PARK 24th edition, Pg. 98 DISEASE 1 – ENDEMIC The cases have remained almost the same – 42 and 43, so it is an endemic DISEASE 2 – EPIDEMIC The cases have increased from 2 to 42, which is alarming and the number of cases in the following week is way more than twice the actual number of cases in the previous week, so it is an epidemic. Epidemic is usually said to occur when the number of cases is more than twice the standard deviation of the usual occurrence. DISEASE 3 – SPORADIC Here the occurrence is irregular. The number diseased has decreased from 6 to 1. There is no temporal relationship or reason explained for this decrease. So it Is a Sporadic.

questions.text: Which of the following wastes are disposed in the Red bag:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref. park 24th edition, Pg. 830 The bag is of Red colour. It is used for reusable plastic wastes like tubings, bottles, intravenous tubes, catheters, syringes without needles, gloves

questions.text: Test is used to compare kaplan Meier Survival Curve:
questions.solution: Answer: (A) Cox proportional hazard test

questions.text: Mid-day meal scheme includes provision of
questions.solution: a Mid Day Meal Scheme under which every child in every Government and Government aided primary school was to be served a prepared Mid Day Meal with a minimum content of 300 calories of energy and 8-12 gram protein per day for a minimum of 200 days

questions.text: A 49 kg primigravida with sedentary lifestyle registers at your clinic. What dietary advice will you give her for the 1st trimester, regarding her calorie intake per day?
questions.solution: Correcct Answer (C) No extra calories As recommended by the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, the first trimester does not require consumption of any additional calories above a woman’s baseline calculated needs. It is recommended that she consume an additional 340 calories in the second trimester, and 450 additional calories during the third trimester.

questions.text: In a subcenter population, the CBR is 20, what should be the rate of ANC registration.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) -In a subcenter area with a crude birth rate of 20 , the expected number of ANC registrations should be approximately 55, so, the best option stands to be 60. -Number of Expected Pregnancies per Year -Expected no. of live births (Y)/year = 20 x 5000/1000 = 100 Total number of Expected Pregnancies Z= Y+ 10% of Y= 100 +10% of100 =110 Expected number of ANC registrations will be half of yearly calculation = 55

questions.text: In comparison to a placebo, the number of adverse outcomes with a drug were seen. What is absolute risk reduction & relative risk reduction for the drug? Patients Adverse outcome Placebo 15224 1804 Drugs 15224 1605
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

choices.text: If it is positive, the patient has the disease
If it is negative, the patient does not have the disease

questions.text: The sensitivity of a diagnostic test is very high. What does it signify.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) High sensitive test has less false negatives

questions.text: When comparing the relationship between two variables, a significant correlation was found between them (P<0.5), though none existed in reality. What type of error is seen in this study?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) -A type I error, also known as an error of the first kind, occurs when the null hypothesis (H0) is true, but is rejected. It is asserting something that is absent, a false hit. - A type II error, also known as an error of the second kind, occurs when the null hypothesis is false, but erroneously fails to be rejected. It is failing to assert what is present, a miss.

questions.text: Under National Health Mission which committee makes plan for village health?
questions.solution: C • VHSNC is at village level which makes health plans. This is headed by panchayat representative. This comitte has asha workers, anganwadi workers and ANMs. Even local school teachers and members of self health group are members of this committee. • Rogi kalyan samiti is a hospital management comitte. It is situated in PHCs onwards. Their function is to manage the infrastructure in hospitals. They have to keep a citizen charter in the hospitals and maintain grievance redressal .

questions.text: Isolation period of measles is.
questions.solution: D measles Onset of catarrhal stage to 3rd day of rash Chicken pox 6 days after onset of rash Influenza 3 days after rash onset cholera , diphtheria 3 days after tetracycline is started Herpes zoster 6 days after the onset of rash Mumps Until swelling subsides Pertussis 3 to 4 weeks or until paroxysms cease Meningococcal meningitis, streptococcal pharyngitis Until first 6 hrs to stopping antibiotic therapy

questions.text: Which of the following tests are used to identify damaged vaccines due to over freezing?
questions.solution: A Shake test is done to identify damage due to over freezing. The vial is shaken and the rate of sedimentation of floccules compared with the test vial. If sedimentation is fast, then vial is discarded. It is applicable for vaccines which are freeze sensitive Eg: HepB, DPT, TT, Td, pentavalent, PCV 10

questions.text: Empty blood bag disposed in which colour bin according to latest BMW management guideline

questions.text: BP is measured for 60 patients the mean and SD before and after treatment with an anti hypertensive and the reduction of risk of HTN is calculated by
questions.solution: A Tests of significance 1. Outcome : qualitative variable a. Between 2 or more groups: chi square test b. Within one group: Mc Nemar test 2. Outcome: Quantitative variable a. Between 2 groups: unpaired T test b. > 2 groups: anova test c. Within one group ( before and after) : paired T test

questions.text: Two groups of patients one with ischaemic stroke and other with haemorrhagic storke were compared in a study. The study is about to compare the mean and SD values of a new parameter between two groups, which of the following tests will you use for the same?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Unpaired T test Tests of significance 1. Outcome : qualitative variable a. Between 2 or more groups: chi square test b. Within one group: Mc Nemar test 2. Outcome: Quantitative variable a. Between 2 groups: unpaired T test b. > 2 groups: anova test c. Within one group ( before and after) : paired T test

questions.text: Direct cash benefit is given under ESI Act for which among the following?
questions.solution: ABCDE Ref: Park 24th Ed/853 Explanation:As provided in Section 46 of the ESI Act, the insured person, their dependents shall be entitled to the following benefits: Sickness Benefit- Periodical payment to any insured person in case of his sickness certified by a duly appointed medical practitioner. Maternity Benefit- Periodic payment to an insured woman in case of miscarriage or sickness arising out of pregnency,premature birth of child, certified by an authority specified in this behalf by the regulation. Disablement Benefit- Periodical payment to any insured person suffering from disablement as a result of an employment injury sustained as an employee under the ESI Act,1948 provisions. Dependent’s Benefit- Periodical payment to dependents of insured person who dies as a result of an employment injury sustained as an employee under ESI Act,1948 provisions. Medical Benefit- Medical treatment for and attendance on insured person. Funeral Expenses- Payment towards expenditure on the funeral of the died insured person.

questions.text: Screening tests are generally?
questions.solution: AE Ref: Park 24th Ed/149 Explanation: The screening test to be applied for a certain disease should have the following criteria: Acceptability Repeatibility/Reliability Validity/Accuracy Others: Simple, Low cost and easy to perform Validity has 2 components, sensitivity and specificity. Ideally a screening test should have both high sensitivity and high specificity.

questions.text: All of the following is true about non parametric test except?
questions.solution: C • Two types of tests: parametric test, non parametric test • Parametric test: assumes normality of a data. Data should be symmetrical. Not used for skewed data a. Student T test b. Paired T test c. ANOVA test • Non-parametrcal test:Normality is not necessary. used for skewed data. Used in presence of any outlier. a. Mann-whittney test b. Wilcoxen signed rank test c. Kruskal wallis test

questions.text: What should be couple protection rate if NRR 1 to be achieved-
questions.solution: B The couple protection rate is the main factor to re- duce the net reproduction rate. The current CPR is 54.8% among the eligible couples in the age group of 15-44 yrs. To bring about a NRR of 1, CPR has to exceed 60%

questions.text: Calculate the pearl index of the contraceptive if out of 20 women, 8 got pregnant in 24 months?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pearl index = [total number of accidental pregnancies ÷ (no. of wome X no. of months)] X 100

questions.text: Paradoxical carriers are

questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Types of dietary fibres are • Cellulose • Pectin • Inulin • Lignin • Beta glucan • Psyllium • Resistant starch

questions.text: Cross product ratio is determined by which study?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Cross product ratio tells us about the odd’s ratio. • Cohort study: risk ratio, attributable risk , incidence, relative attributable risk, proportional attributable risk. • Cross sectional studies: point prevalence • Randomized control trial: NNT ( number needed to treat) • Longitudinal study: period prevalence

questions.text: In a normal curve, what is the area that comes between one standard deviation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • ± 1 SD: 68% • ± 2 SD: 95% • ± 3 SD: 99%

questions.text: 2 year old boy of weight 12kg with vitamin A deficiency comes to you. What is the oral dose of vitamin A to be given?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Not a personal protective equipment is
questions.solution: Andwer (D)

choices.text: Factor associated with both exposure and the disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups
Factor associated with exposure only and is distributed unequally in study and control groups
Factor associated with both exposure and disease and is distributed equally in study and control groups
Factor associated with disease only and is distributed equally in study and control groups

questions.text: Confounding factor is defined as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Confounding factor is associated with both disease and exposure. It is unequally distributed. • Has independent effect in causation of outcome • Methods of removing confounders a. Randomization: it removes both known and unknown confounders. b. Matching c. Restriction d. Modelling e. stratification

questions.text: The significance of difference between proportions can be tested by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Proportions talks about non-parametric test ie chi square test • T test is parametric and for difference between two grou[s • ANOVA is parametric and for more than two groups • Correlation and regression tells about relationship

choices.text: Test used to assess quantitative observations before and after an intervention
Test that is used when the observations are in the form of proportions ( qualitative data)
Test applied when separate observations are made on individuals of two separate groups and then needs to be compared

questions.text: Paired T test is defined as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Paired T test are done for two groups . it is a parametric test hence quantitative

questions.text: best representation of incidence of disease in different time line is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Change in incidence over a time period represents trends. Trends are better depicted through line diagrams.

questions.text: for trench type of sanitary filling, the amount of land required for 2 meter deep trench for 10000 population is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Factual question.

questions.text: Risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an epidemiological indicator?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Malarial indices a. Spleen rate: 2nd best indicator of malaria prevalence b. Infant parasite rate: most sensitive index of recent transmission in ocality and evaluation of whole program. c. Annual blood examination rate (ABER): index of operational efficiency and fever prevalence d. Annual parasitic index: best indicator of malaria in community e. Slide positivity rate: important for a good outbreak indicator

questions.text: Health center in remote area for planning and programming and management od schemes is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Planning and programming of various health schemes are done at PHC level.PHC

questions.text: Dose of diptheria antitoxin for mild and early pharyngeal cases is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dose of diptheria antitoxin is • Mild and early pharyngeal cases: 20,000 to 40,000 units • Moderate to severe cases: 40,000 to 60,000 units • Severe , extensive and late cases: 80,000 to 1 lakh units

questions.text: Vertical transmission in HIV is highest when
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Elective c section is protective as normal delivery has higher chances of transmission of HIV • Pre mature delivery has increased chances of transmission than term delivery • Transmission depends on high viral load

questions.text: Which method is used to study the following timeline?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Cohort is used for follow up • Cross sectional study is for single point of timeline • Case control: retrospective • Randomized control trials have artificial interventions
